I doubt this is a bug by design.
When we do aggregate-add/remove-host or aggregate-set-metadata, we are actually altering records in the aggregate_hosts or aggregate_metadata table respectively instead of aggregate table. Only  when trying to update the name of a aggregate, the name of the corresponding aggregate table record will get refreshed. So IMO the mechanism is logical and these behaviors are expected.'}, {'account_id': 25562, 'date': '2018-08-10 09:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Code-Review

> I doubt this is a bug by design.
 > When we do aggregate-add/remove-host or aggregate-set-metadata, we
 > are actually altering records in the aggregate_hosts or
 > aggregate_metadata table respectively instead of aggregate table.
 > Only  when trying to update the name of a aggregate, the name of
 > the corresponding aggregate table record will get refreshed. So IMO
 > the mechanism is logical and these behaviors are expected.

By "the name of the corresponding aggregate table record will get refreshed" I mean the updated_at column are then updated consequently.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-08-27 09:48:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> > I doubt this is a bug by design.
 > > When we do aggregate-add/remove-host or aggregate-set-metadata,
 > we
 > > are actually altering records in the aggregate_hosts or
 > > aggregate_metadata table respectively instead of aggregate table.
 > > Only  when trying to update the name of a aggregate, the name of
 > > the corresponding aggregate table record will get refreshed. So
 > IMO
 > > the mechanism is logical and these behaviors are expected.
 > 
 > By "the name of the corresponding aggregate table record will get
 > refreshed" I mean the updated_at column are then updated
 > consequently.
Hi Chen. Thanks for the review. According to your comments this is not a bug to be fixed??'}, {'account_id': 25562, 'date': '2018-08-27 12:55:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> > > I doubt this is a bug by design.
 > > > When we do aggregate-add/remove-host or aggregate-set-metadata,
 > > we
 > > > are actually altering records in the aggregate_hosts or
 > > > aggregate_metadata table respectively instead of aggregate
 > table.
 > > > Only  when trying to update the name of a aggregate, the name
 > of
 > > > the corresponding aggregate table record will get refreshed. So
 > > IMO
 > > > the mechanism is logical and these behaviors are expected.
 > >
 > > By "the name of the corresponding aggregate table record will get
 > > refreshed" I mean the updated_at column are then updated
 > > consequently.
 > Hi Chen. Thanks for the review. According to your comments this is
 > not a bug to be fixed??

Although there is an argument that if the hosts or metadata of an aggregate is changed, the aggregate itself is therefore updated consequently, the current behaviors also make sense in that changes are made to different tables. Unless there is a need to rely on the "updated_at" column of the aggregate table to get an idea about when any modification to the aggregate is made latest, I prefer not to make the change.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-30 16:34:21.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This is old and in merge conflict. I've marked the bug as wishlist/opinion and if someone wants to pursue this I'd suggest bringing it up on the mailing list. As noted earlier, we've had similar discussions about things like updating the parent instance action when one of it's child events is updated/created. Looks like we moved forward with updating the action record's updated_at when the event was finished (updated):

I75a827b759b59773c08ffc6b1e3e54d6189b5853

So we do have precedence for doing this."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-01-10 12:47:34.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

In addition to the comments from dansmith, he also suggested we do the updating via a function in oslo.db, just to ensure we're using the same format that TimestampMixin does. dansmith suggested a 'touch' method. We could go one step further and start using relationships to ensure we always update the 'updated_at' for parents when a child changes, avoiding the need to manually call 'touch()' for a parent whenever we modify a child, but that would be more work of course"}]

commit_message:
Populate 'updated_at' when aggregate is updated

Showing an exist aggregate, the "updated_at" in it's resonse body
is always NULL. We will save the last updated time of aggregate
in following cases:

  add_host
  delete_host

Co-Authored-By: Brin Zhang <zhangbailin@inspur.com>

Closes-Bug: #1663456
Change-Id: I61fcdf0226a88edd466f47e4dd20625143a53c5a

> (1 comment)

Hi Matt, 

Verified suggested joined load column idea. Updated [1] by joining 'block_device_mapping' and verified performance improvement. 
It’s improving performance drastically provided the usage period requested by an user has instances which are not deleted. 
If there are too many deleted instances, there is no performance gain. 

Please give your feedback on the latest patch and then accordingly I will add required unit/functional tests.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/instance.py#L50"}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-01-15 08:35:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi All,

The unit test is failing because the newly introduce ’is_volume_backed’ attribute is just a field in the Instance object and not the column in instance db table so that causes problem while  getting the instance from db.

So to over come this issue I am planning to introduce new parameter ‘transient_attrs’ in method “”   which will be the list of attributes (which are not present in the db table) passed from api to db on basis of which it will execute selective query to return required results. 

Will upload the patch soon.

-Bhagyashri'}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2019-08-20 05:53:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Hi All,

The unit test is failing because the newly introduce ’is_volume_backed’ attribute is just a field in the Instance object and not the column in instance db table so that causes problem while  getting the instance from db.

So to over come this issue I am planning to introduce new parameter ‘transient_attrs’ in method “nova/objects/instance/InstanceList.get_active_by_window_joined” which will be the list of attributes (which are not present in the db table) passed from api to db on basis of which it will execute selective query to return required results. 
Will upload the patch soon.

-Bhagyashri'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2019-08-21 10:03:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Hi Gorka Eguileor,

Thanks for review!

In case of simple tenant usage api there will be impact on  performance to get the instance list, if we add `is_volume_backed` in `obj_extra_fields` list because in that case it will need to query bdms for each instance to check whether an instance is booted from volume or not.

I have uploaded new patch set #12 with new approach. I would like your insights on it."}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2019-08-22 09:29:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

(3 comments)

Sorry, I'm clearly not the right person to review this, because Cinder's OVOs implementation details are different.

For example the `obj_to_primitive` function is a method of the OVO itself, so it's easy to override it to include additional data like the `is_volume_backend` attribute on serialization.

So in Cinder we wouldn't include it as a `field` (since it doesn't have a DB field in the ORM instance) and we would handle it separately with the `obj_to_primitive`, `obj_make_compatible`, `_obj_load_attr`, etc."}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-08-22 10:01:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I think this should at least be split into two changes, one with the DB layer changes for the new is_volume_backed model query stuff and another for the API change to use that. The DB model code is going to require some additional scrutiny and doing all of that in the same review might be tough. I think there should probably also be a "fixes" release note in the patch with the API changes to explain the behavior change in the os-simple-tenant-usage API. I don't think a microversion is necessary for fixing this, but a release note should be included.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-09-19 14:35:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

To be clear, I don't think this is going to land in Train, we're 1 week from RC1 and this is extremely latent behavior.

The extra table join could have a considerable performance impact when listing instances in this API, and I've always heard that this API is already performing poorly - and is the first thing a user hits when logging into Horizon, so I think we need someone more DB model / performance minded to review the changes there in isolation which is why I asked that it be split up. This is something I'd ask Jay Pipes to look into (the DB model query changes) but he longer works on OpenStack so it would need to be someone else at this point like Mike Bayer (zzzeek in IRC)."}, {'account_id': 27302, 'date': '2019-11-15 07:18:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 27302, 'date': '2019-11-15 07:21:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

 > works on OpenStack so it would need to be someone else at this
 > point like Mike Bayer (zzzeek in IRC).

Hi Matt,
For performance impact, verified 'Simple Tenant API' requests using rally.
Here created instances (booted from with volume(BFV) and without volume), and send 'Simple Tenant API' request over 25 threads. And verified on master repository and branch where changes done.

Please refer:
1. summary and script to genrate Data 	>> http://paste.openstack.org/show/786166/
2. report_master_500_1000_25.html	>> http://paste.openstack.org/show/786167/
3. report_changes_500_1000_25.html	>> http://paste.openstack.org/show/786168/

need to check another two patches'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-14 18:49:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24: Code-Review-1

Are we just punting on a microversion for this? Anyone that has code that consumes our API and does some stats calculation could be looking at the embedded flavor and subtracting the relevant bits in order to come up with something sane. If that code doesn't have a way to know whether this new behavior is enabled or not, how can they make their script continue to work?

-1 for visibility of this question."}, {'account_id': 27302, 'date': '2020-01-16 07:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

> Are we just punting on a microversion for this? Anyone that has
 > code that consumes our API and does some stats calculation could be
 > looking at the embedded flavor and subtracting the relevant bits in
 > order to come up with something sane. If that code doesn't have a
 > way to know whether this new behavior is enabled or not, how can
 > they make their script continue to work?
 > 
 > -1 for visibility of this question.

Just to confirm, since its bug fix, we want micro-version for this change as the "local_gb" calculation logic has been changed.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-23 08:15:32.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore root_gb for BFV in simple tenant usage API

The simple tenant usage API does not show correct disk_gb usage
if instance is booted from volume.

Added check "is_volume_backed_instance" to ignore root_gb for
calculating local_gb usage.

Change-Id: I2ea3e99ad04702787fc707debe11367437755be0
Closes-Bug: #1715570

'}, {'created': '2019-08-22 07:29:32.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore root_gb for BFV in simple tenant usage API

Added "is_volume_backed" field in "Instance which will be set
to True/False depending on whether the instance is booted from
volume or not.
This attribute should be set in the expected_attrs and passed
to InstanceList method like
"objects.InstanceList.get_active_by_window_joined" when you want
to get a list of instances and iterate over the instance to find
whether an instance is booted from volume or not otherwise you
will need to query bdms for each instance thereby impacting the
performance of the simple tenant usage API.

Co-Authored-By: Bhagyashri Shewale <bhagyashri.shewale@nttdata.com>
Closes-Bug: #1715570
Change-Id: I2ea3e99ad04702787fc707debe11367437755be0

commit_message:
Ignore root_gb if instance is booted from volume

If instance is booted from volume, disk usage calculation should
exclude flavor.root_gb in case of Simple Tenant Usage API and
Instance Usage Audit Period Task.

Co-Authored-By: Bhagyashri Shewale <bhagyashri.shewale@nttdata.com>
Closes-Bug: #1715570
Change-Id: I2ea3e99ad04702787fc707debe11367437755be0

Allow "is_volume_backend" to be passed as expected_attrs so that it
can set "is_volume_backed" attribute to True/False in Instance object
depending on whether it is booted from volume or not.

'is_volume_backend' column doesn't exists in the instances db table,
it's just defined as an optional field which will be included in the
db query only in special cases like getting list of instances for a
specific period for now.

commit_message:
Instance object changes for the new 'is_volume_backed' expected_attr

Allow "is_volume_backend" to be passed as expected_attrs so that it
can set "is_volume_backed" attribute to True/False in Instance object
depending on whether it is booted from volume or not.

'is_volume_backend' column doesn't exists in the instances db table,
it's just defined as an optional field which will be included in the
db query only in special cases like getting list of instances for a
specific period for now.

Partial-Bug: #1715570
Change-Id: Ic71cdae7d10a0af7fffa596702b621695331252e

commit_message:
Remove zVM requirement from the top level requirements.

Requirements for just one hypervisor driver should not appear in
requirements.txt. This has been a long standing policy. Otherwise
we're forcing deployers to install a dependancy that the vast
majority of them will never use. Instead, dynamically load the
depedancy at run time.

Change-Id: I6af2fe2a1d915ffc86ad3d73aa5f04a09a93d867

hi, melanie

that periodic task seems different with this one trying to address. and that one seems been deleted? only configuration stil there.

fix me.'}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2019-01-18 08:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

hi, melanie

In current _cleanup_running_deleted_instances, if DB don't have the information of a running instance(not even been marked as 'deleted' instance ) , it then raise an exception and ignore. 

here,we are going to clean up that kind of instance.

we maybe could enhance that logic. the current implement (this one) is suggested by starlingx. 

we might need refactor. 

thanks."}, {'account_id': 28715, 'date': '2019-01-18 15:31:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The existing _cleanup_running_deleted_instances() periodic audit calls _running_deleted_instances, and finds instances that were deleted, and have 'deleted' attribute in database.

I think it would be helpful to describe in the commit message how an orphan can be created. There may be a few ways for this to occur, but historically the most common way was a result of some sort of failure after live-migration started and not cleaning up completely in live-migration rollback due to unhandled exception. Say we lose the host with the conductor mid-migration, and the live-migration completes. The result are 2 identical VMs -- one of them becomes an orphan that is not tracked in nova but is still seen by libvirt."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-01-18 15:40:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> The existing _cleanup_running_deleted_instances() periodic audit
 > calls _running_deleted_instances, and finds instances that were
 > deleted, and have 'deleted' attribute in database.
 > 
 > I think it would be helpful to describe in the commit message how
 > an orphan can be created. There may be a few ways for this to
 > occur, but historically the most common way was a result of some
 > sort of failure after live-migration started and not cleaning up
 > completely in live-migration rollback due to unhandled exception.
 > Say we lose the host with the conductor mid-migration, and the
 > live-migration completes. The result are 2 identical VMs -- one of
 > them becomes an orphan that is not tracked in nova but is still
 > seen by libvirt.

Thanks, this would be a good example to use in the commit message.

@Yongli, thanks for explaining how this patch is addressing a different scenario. I misunderstood your commit message. I'll leave the -1 on here for a need to improve the commit message to describe the problem and solution better.

This also might qualify as a bug fix rather than a blueprint, but let me get a few more opinions first."}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2019-01-29 08:09:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

melanie witt, working on this. thanks.'}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2019-01-29 08:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-01-29 10:52:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just a suggestion, but if I were doing this, I would probably split this into at least two changes, one for the virt driver changes and then one for the compute manager changes to use the new virt driver APIs. As it is, this is a very large and therefore hard to review change, especially to make sure there is adequate test coverage. If the change was logically split up it would be easier to review it in parts and make sure there is adequate test coverage for the various conditions and error handling.'}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2019-04-01 01:28:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-15 07:25:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I think this patch should focus on the cleanup of 'non tracked' instance.

The 'non tracked' instance means the instance have no DB record in Nova, but existed in the hypevisor.

For the live migraiton case, I think should leave it to Luyao's fix https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/track-err-migr-and-orphans-in-RT

I think the current fix is right. Although the existing nova code include the cleanup for the instance is deleted but have instance in dest hypervisor. I think that part should be moved to _incomplete_migration_cleanup method later by luyao's fix. Since in the middle of live migration, if both dest and src down, the dest VM's xml cleanup by libvirt, but the resources for that instance on the dest doesn't cleanup. So if we depend on this method to cleanup that case, that won't work, since the xml already cleanup by libvirt. We should figure out that case by DB query, not the hypervisor return.

So the current path only append the cleanup for non-tracked instance, and keep other behaviour same as before, then the patch LGTM."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-19 00:22:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42:

(5 comments)

Thanks for your comments, Alex. I've replied inline but this change is complicated and it's possible I have missed something. We really could use more reviewers on this patch."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-19 00:25:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-19 05:02:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-20 02:43:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-20 16:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

I just want to say that I think this is too complicated and fragile to be something we should merge. It depends on a new driver method that guesses about running VMs to determine if they used to be nova instances, but that is only implemented for libvirt. I don't know if other hypervisors are able to make that guess, or how accurate it would be.

IMHO, the reason we retain deleted records in the DB is precisely for this kind of thing, so that we have time to lazily clean up referential data. DB archive and purge has a limit for a reason. Building more complexity into our periodic to account for the situation where compute was down, an instance was deleted, and you are aggressively purging your database just seems ...ugh. Deleting VMs (optionally) on compute restart that look like nova instances but have no record would be less gross, a little more predictable. Doing it in a periodic where it may overlap with migrate (or cross-cell migrate, or shelve) just seems like a bad plan to me."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-20 18:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

(2 comments)

Replies to existing comments inline, but overall I have to admit I don't like this idea given the complexity of the implementation.

At the PTGs, we thought the high-level idea sounded OK but the implementation has proved to be complex and brittle. Given that the "unknown vms" problem can be easily avoided by using the --before flag on archive_deleted_rows, I'm not sure this periodic task modification is worth the complexity.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-20 19:38:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-20 20:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-21 02:24:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42:

emm...I think I agree with Dan, I did have question 'why the operator archive the db so quick' cross my mind. unless there is approve for other case we don't have DB entry for an instance."}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2019-11-21 02:40:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

Thanks, your concerns are definitely reasonable for me. I gonna raise this problem and concerns to edge team, to find out what exactly makes the VM DB record disappear. and then'}, {'account_id': 28715, 'date': '2019-12-04 17:18:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 42:

Dan, Melanie, Alex, Yongli,
In this lengthy discussion, we have somehow lost the essence how we even get orphan instances. Perhaps we are missing a real system multi-node testcase to trigger this. Please review my first comments from Patch set 1 (Jan 18, 2019).

The reason I had written our version of orphan audit for our production environment, was that we frequently got orphans during robustness testing (like simulate Dead Office, power off) and stress scenarios with lots of in-flight migrations and evacuations.

The consequences of an orphan was bad. This was exaggerated when configuring hugepages since resource accounting is mismatched with reality. Tendency is for scheduler to pick on a compute that is actually out of memory.  The result is either a libvirt allocation error and compute claim failure, OR, linux OOM killer which can shoot down things random things down you don't expect. Once that happens system is unstable.  Worst case, it possible to have duplicate running VMs with the same IP address, but I never actually proved that. Only way to fix the problem is to reboot the problem compute, and have nova-compute run through its init and cleanup and destroy what it thinks are evacuated instances.

Likely scenario to cause orphan:
* perform parallel live-migrations and parallel cold-migrations, evacuations, repeat over and over with multiple computes in the mix, allocate lots of hugepages, and allocate enough VMs with hugepages that you get resource constrained per host, some VMs with big disks that are actually touched. If the VM touches big disk, then qemu will consume lots of 4K overhead memory (outside of VMs hugepages) to handle dynamic IO just to launch the VM.
* reboot the host running the nova-conductor mid-migration, OR, kill rabbitmq process 'at the right time' on conductor node.

At one point we saw rabbitmq die for some reason which likely caused similar problem. Can simulate by manually killing rabbitmq process 'just at the right time' but that is very hard to do. I was able to do enough repeated robustness testing to trigger orphans to test the orphan audit. I would also manually insert faults into various code-paths I could think of for  live-migration (pre-migration, post-migration, networking failure, cinder failure, manually create memory hog in linux), then hammer it. ;)  In some cases that type of testing eventually leads to other RT fixes for stale numa_topology, RT pinning robustness, live-migration rollback robustness, etc. In theory with more fixes, it gets harder to create an orphan.

IMHO, I don't think it reasonable for a production environment with nova to have VMs managed outside of nova's knowledge. nova/libvirt expects that it understands a host in its entirety and does not share resources.  Eg, do  not support two separate nova on same host. Do not support launch qemu directly or via libvirt on same host that nova is running. Following this logic in production environment, IMHO the default behaviour should be to 'reap' orphans and expect the host does not have two independent brains.

What I had said Jan 18, 2019:
The existing _cleanup_running_deleted_instances() periodic audit calls _running_deleted_instances, and finds instances that were deleted, and have 'deleted' attribute in database.

I think it would be helpful to describe in the commit message how an orphan can be created. There may be a few ways for this to occur, but historically the most common way was a result of some sort of failure after live-migration started and not cleaning up completely in live-migration rollback due to unhandled exception. Say we lose the host with the conductor mid-migration, and the live-migration completes. The result are 2 identical VMs -- one of them becomes an orphan that is not tracked in nova but is still seen by libvirt."}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2019-12-16 02:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 42:

Hi, Jim

In this long discuss the term we used to describe the 'orphans' had changed a little bit. 

we classify the 'orphans' into 2 class:
•"not tracked":  The VＭ is totally not tracked by the Nova DB. There is no record in the DB anymore.
• "moved"： VM running on "wrong"  host according to the DB. These "moved" instances are explained in your previous reply.

But currently, the big concern is about the first type orphans: "not tracked".

It seems that the only way to generating such a 'not tracked' VM is by "archive" and "purge“  the DB in the wrong timing/method.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-29 07:26:41.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up orphan instances

This peaordic task instances that are listed in the hypervisor
on a given compute node but are not listed in the nova database
as running on that compute node.

Instances in the middle of migration or waiting for resize/migrate
confirmation will not be destroyed.

bp: periodic-orphan-instances-delete

Change-Id: Ie9fe8bd25f4625161d529ecdcc2822fc9d614083
Co-Authored-By: Chris Friesen <chris.friesen@windriver.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-01-29 08:15:19.000000000', 'message': "Clean up orphan instances

  The existing _cleanup_running_deleted_instances() periodic audit
calls _running_deleted_instances, and finds instances that were
deleted, and have 'deleted' attribute in database.

  There may be a few ways an instance is not listed in the Database
at all. For example,there is some sort of failure after
live-migration started and not cleaning up completely in
live-migration rollback due to unhandled exception. The
live-migration completes. The result are 2 identical VMs -- one of
them becomes an orphan that is not tracked in nova but is still
seen by libvirt.

  This commit introduce a new periodic clean task to query vm from
libvirt and deleted them if they are not tracking by Nova.

bp: periodic-orphan-instances-delete

Change-Id: Ie9fe8bd25f4625161d529ecdcc2822fc9d614083
Co-Authored-By: Chris Friesen <chris.friesen@windriver.com>

"}, {'created': '2019-03-27 07:23:16.000000000', 'message': "Clean up orphan instances

The existing _cleanup_running_deleted_instances() periodic audit
calls _running_deleted_instances, and finds instances that were
deleted, and have 'deleted' attribute in database.

There may be a few ways an instance is not listed in the Database
at all. For example,there is some sort of failure after
live-migration started and not cleaning up completely in
live-migration rollback due to unhandled exception. The
live-migration completes. The result are 2 identical VMs -- one of
them becomes an orphan that is not tracked in nova but is still
seen by libvirt.

This commit introduce a new periodic clean task to query vm from
libvirt and deleted them if they are not tracking by Nova. This is
configurable via option running_orphan_instance_action.

Closes-Bug: #1820802

Change-Id: Ie9fe8bd25f4625161d529ecdcc2822fc9d614083
Co-Authored-By: Chris Friesen <chris.friesen@windriver.com>

"}, {'created': '2019-04-01 07:48:27.000000000', 'message': "Clean up orphan instances

The existing _cleanup_running_deleted_instances() periodic audit
calls _running_deleted_instances, and finds instances that were
deleted, and have 'deleted' attribute in database.

There may be an instance is not listed in the Database at all. For
example,there is some sort of failure after live-migration started
and not cleaning up completely in live-migration rollback due to
unhandled exception. The live-migration completes. The result are
2 identical VMs -- one of them becomes an orphan that is not tracked
as running in source host but is still running and consuming
resources.

And if delete an instance while the nova-compute service is down,
the instance will became orphan and is not tracked by nova database.

This commit introduce a new periodic clean task to query vm from
libvirt and deleted them if they are not tracking by Nova. Which
action is taken is configurable via option
'running_orphan_instance_action'.

Change-Id: Ie9fe8bd25f4625161d529ecdcc2822fc9d614083
Closes-Bug: #1820802

There may be an instance is not listed in the Database at all. For
example,there is some sort of failure after live-migration started
and not cleaning up completely in live-migration rollback due to
unhandled exception. The live-migration completes. The result are
2 identical VMs -- one of them becomes an orphan that is not tracked
as running in source host but is still running and consuming
resources.

And if delete an instance while the nova-compute service is down, and
the database is purged, the instance will became orphan and is not
tracked by nova database.

This commit introduce a new periodic clean task to query vm from
libvirt and deleted them if they are not tracking by Nova. Which
action is taken is configurable via option
'running_orphan_instance_action'.

Change-Id: Ie9fe8bd25f4625161d529ecdcc2822fc9d614083
Closes-Bug: #1820802

commit_message:
clean up orphan instances

The existing _cleanup_running_deleted_instances() periodic audit
calls _running_deleted_instances, and finds instances that were
deleted, and have 'deleted' attribute in database.

If delete an instance while the nova-compute service is down, and
the database is purged, the instance will became orphan and is not
tracked by nova database.

This commit add "shutdown_unknown" and "reap_unknown" options to
_cleanup_running_deleted_instances periodic task.

Change-Id: Ie9fe8bd25f4625161d529ecdcc2822fc9d614083
Closes-Bug: #1820802

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-12-20 06:30:46.000000000', 'message': 'Don't create instance_extra entry for deleted instance

When updating an instance, if there is no entry for an instance,
nova create a new entry for it. For somehow, if updating comes after
the instance has been deleted (its entry would be soft-deleted),
nova would create a new entry for the deleted instance currently.
It causes instance_extra entry duplicate.

For those deleted instance, we shouldn't create a new entry,
just let's skip the "update".

Change-Id: I28e3fb3ef20508d83f30ae6af8bf94967486f6c8
Closes-bug: #1651319
'}, {'created': '2016-12-20 12:08:45.000000000', 'message': 'Don't create instance_extra entry for deleted instance

When updating an instance, if there is no entry for an instance,
nova create a new entry for it. For somehow, if updating comes after
the instance has been deleted (its entry would be soft-deleted),
nova would create a new entry for the deleted instance currently.
It causes instance_extra entry duplicate.

For those deleted instance, we shouldn't create a new entry,

commit_message:
Don't create instance_extra entry for deleted instance

When updating an instance, if there is no entry for an instance,
nova create a new entry for it. For somehow, if updating comes after
the instance has been deleted (its entry would be soft-deleted),
nova would create a new entry for the deleted instance currently.
It causes instance_extra entry duplicate.

For those deleted instance, we shouldn't create a new entry,
just let's skip the "update".

Change-Id: I28e3fb3ef20508d83f30ae6af8bf94967486f6c8
Closes-bug: #1651319

commit_message:
Check enable_new_services option in service.py

In order to make enable_new_services option configurable per host
not per process which can directly access to database, nova should
check enable_new_services option before try to access database or
call rpc for conductor.

Change-Id: I0f1801b7a840afd557013e31d1cbc91511e0ff81
Closes-Bug: #1747484

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-07 03:07:18.000000000', 'message': 'VMware:fix get VM root device conditional verify

the old code in "class /nova/virt/vmwareapi/vm_util.py method : get_vmdk_info ",
verifies the root device uses "path.basename == root_disk+".vmdk",
but when one snapshots a VM ,
the root device has an different filepath from a normal image filepath,
it's like "root_disk+"-"+"*.vmdk".
This patch enables get_root_device() to work for both normal and snapshot filepaths.
for the case of VM snapshot of VMware, because the format is
like "root_disk_<number>.vmdk".

Change-Id: I0a8046e467ed60d707ab7636872b7956bde9e599
Closes-Bug: #1634340

This patch enables get_root_device() to work for both normal and snapshot filepaths.
for the case of VM snapshot of VMware, because the format is
like "root_disk_<number>.vmdk".

Change-Id: I0a8046e467ed60d707ab7636872b7956bde9e599
Closes-Bug: #1634340
'}]
commit_message:
VMware:fix get VM root device conditional verify

the old code in "class /nova/virt/vmwareapi/vm_util.py method : get_vmdk_info ",
verifies the root device uses "path.basename == root_disk+".vmdk",
but when one snapshots a VM ,
the root device has an different filepath from a normal image filepath,
it's like "root_disk+"-"+"*.vmdk".
This patch enables get_root_device() to work for both normal and snapshot filepaths.
for the case of VM snapshot of VMware, because the format is
like "root_disk_<number>.vmdk".

Change-Id: I0a8046e467ed60d707ab7636872b7956bde9e599
Closes-Bug: #1634340

commit_message:
Add warning message for cache_utils connection failure

We don't provide enough information to pinpoint something like a
memcache connection info. Leave some breadcrumbs to help users.

Change-Id: I0ff2b3c738979faf5393de5e6ccfc4f93c15e500
Closes-Bug: #1715785

commit_message:
Use Placement API to check resource usage

Use the following API to confirm that resource usage is
correctly reflected at create server.
Test is choice small flavor at create server and
choice large flavor at create server
<https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/placement/#list-resource-provider-usages>

Change-Id: I7ffe98eeb3ed0723584b08b233605231e9a91c12

commit_message:
Inline trace_request_filter

The logic for tracing a request filter was very simple. Rather than
having a decorator and remembering to put it on new filter methods, move
the logic inline in process_reqspec.

This will also make it easier to include things that aren't plain
methods in ALL_REQUEST_FILTERS.

Change-Id: Ia9cad7dfa852a61b294848249916fbf3aa70e4d4

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-21 03:32:49.000000000', 'message': 'Whether to use configdrive disk depends on instance.configdrive

Use instance.configdrive to decide whether to create or use
configdrive disk or not, and cfg combined with instance.configdrive
to decide how to change instance.configdrive in db.

commit_message:
Whether to use config drive depends on instance.configdrive

Use instance.config_drive in db to decide whether to create
a config drive or not. Combine cfg with instance.config_drive
to decide how to change instance.config_drive in db.

Change-Id: I924a381ebc7bb40bc98852fe0f19ec0f8d836883
Closes-Bug: #1241806
Closes-Bug: #1303714

commit_message:
Block automatic transport_url update for cell0

nova-manage cell_v2 map_cell0 creates the cell0 mapping based
on database_connection alone and transport_url is set to "none://".
As cell0 does not contain any message queues unlike other
cells and by default, its configuration is the same as that of
the nova_API cell, when running the nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell
command it doesn't make sense to always pass "--transport_url="none://"
to avoid overwriting from the api.conf. This patch disallows
transport_url update for cell0.

Change-Id: I1893009e7e7eda576fd5b4ee9b1141ae00ff2b84
Closes-Bug: #1794493

commit_message:
Raise Exception instead of Exception method call

This patch replace in the unit test an Exception()
method call to raise Exception().
In another patch[1] require to track the raised exception for
notification transformation implementation, but the Exception() only a
method call, not contains real error informations, however we need it.
Instead I raised a real Exception which are trackable, contains
informations from raised exceptions and appropriate for the target.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/482629/

Change-Id: I304efe1146d7f80e0d2d44888d4efef49fb9ec0b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-25 10:38:14.000000000', 'message': 'created AggregateSubnetAvailabilityFilter

This is a filter that looks at the available ip capacity for individual subnets.

It acomplishes this by looking at a "subnets" key that needs to be set as a property of aggregates that hosts are members of and in order to pass the filter one of the subnets the host has access to must not be out of IP capacity.
The value for "subnets" should be a comma seperated list of subnet names that hosts within the aggregate have access to.

This is effectively a work around for https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: Ifa73d40763917cd9dbcbff75a8234c11ccdc5ed0

commit_message:
created AggregateSubnetAvailabilityFilter

This is a filter that looks at the available ip capacity for individual subnets.

It acomplishes this by looking at a "subnets" key that needs to be set as a property of aggregates that hosts are members of and in order to pass the filter one of the subnets the host has access to must not be out of IP capacity.
The value for "subnets" should be a comma seperated list of subnet names that hosts within the aggregate have access to.

This is effectively a work around for https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: Ifa73d40763917cd9dbcbff75a8234c11ccdc5ed0

commit_message:
Fix unit of hw_rng:rate_period

Replace seconds with milliseconds
in the description of hw_rng:rate_period.

* https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsRng

NOTE(takashin):
  The conflict is due to not having
  Ia57c93ef1e72ccf134ba6fc7fcb85ab228d68a47 in stable/pike.

commit_message:
Fix 'has_calls' method calls in unit tests

The 'has_calls' method does not exist in assertion methods of mock.
Replace the 'has_calls' method with an 'assert_has_calls' method or
an 'assert_called_once_with' method.
Add an 'assertEqual' check before an 'assert_has_calls' method.

Conflicts:
    nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

NOTE(takashin): The conflict is due to not having the following change
in stable/ocata.

    Id7a05b579ead6ac5445ca5b1eeab6d223d545a6c

Change-Id: I4b606fce473d064b9bb00213696c075cea020aaf

[{'created': '2019-08-14 00:56:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix misuse of nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims

The nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims returns True or False.
It does not assert anything.
So the return value should be asserted in tests.

Add assertTrue where the nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims is called.

    nova/tests/functional/db/test_build_request.py
    nova/tests/unit/objects/test_build_request.py

commit_message:
Fix misuse of nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims

The nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims returns True or False.
It does not assert anything.
So the return value should be asserted in tests.

Add assertTrue where the nova.objects.base.obj_equal_prims is called.

Conflicts:
    nova/tests/unit/objects/test_build_request.py

NOTE(takashin): The conflict is due to not having the following change
in stable/ocata.

    I1121eaf24856dcb74f07c224531a821b3cdc46fc

Change-Id: I49460ec3b572ee14b32229e771a5499ff91e8722
Closes-Bug: #1839853
(cherry picked from commit 5c1d9dcbb29f5a84d56c4e496b3111b4040cad13)
(cherry picked from commit a8e19afb3d4889412ee6f539bb63865eb8ef5bb5)
(cherry picked from commit a17bb97b2eb1f8657423f2ecbbfbfb9b1b629ae7)
(cherry picked from commit 151c828b1f498d44342d9265e575e5fdcb0783c1)
(cherry picked from commit a926d356d08ad4b00c0e810053b20bfd9c46ac41)

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/667047/10 : SUCCESS in 2h 18m 35s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-09 18:05:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Note that I don't think we have said anywhere that you can't run the upgrade checks before syncing the database(s), just that's how we test it in grenade. Which means running the upgrade checks before the sync is undefined, but that doesn't mean it's broken. So I'm not sure I totally agree with the bug, but if we were going to officially support both modes then I guess we should test both modes in grenade (run the checks before and after db sync)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-09 18:51:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Some related discussion in IRC today:

commit_message:
Add database schema upgrade check

Add database schema upgrade checks
in the 'nova-status upgrade check' command.

Change-Id: I8aa48f9608a992e1739268a8378f1cf805b8dca9
Closes-Bug: #1833278

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-31 05:06:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix default values in update_cell command

If specifying either --transport-url or --database_connection
only in the nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell command,
the value in the configuration file is used for the option
that is not specified.
It causes the following error.

The specified transport_url and/or database_connection
combination already exists for another cell
with uuid 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000.

So change the default value to the original value of
the cell mapping instead of the value
in the configuration file.

Change-Id: If5b5bbdc928594d0f53a50dac7349af694a07b7c
Closes-Bug: #1829852
'}, {'created': '2019-06-11 03:55:27.000000000', 'message': "Fix default values in update_cell command

If specifying either --transport-url or --database_connection
only in the nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell command,
the value in the configuration file is used for the option
that is not specified.
It causes the following error.

The specified transport_url and/or database_connection
combination already exists for another cell
with uuid 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000.

So change the command as follows:

* Use the value in the configuration file
  if neither transport_url or database_connection is specified.
* Keep the value as it is if 'keep' is specified
  for transport_url or database_connection.
* The command exits with a return code of 6
  if either transport_url or database_connection is specified
  and the other is not specified.

Change-Id: If5b5bbdc928594d0f53a50dac7349af694a07b7c
Closes-Bug: #1829852

commit_message:
Fix default values in update_cell command

If specifying either --transport-url or --database_connection
only in the nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell command,
the value in the configuration file is used for the option
that is not specified.
It causes the following error.

The specified transport_url and/or database_connection
combination already exists for another cell
with uuid 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000.

So change the command as follows:

* Use the value in the configuration file
  if neither transport_url or database_connection is specified.
* Keep the value as it is if 'keep' is specified
  for transport_url or database_connection.
* The command exits with a return code of 6
  if either transport_url or database_connection is specified
  and the other is not specified.

Change-Id: If5b5bbdc928594d0f53a50dac7349af694a07b7c
Closes-Bug: #1829852

commit_message:
Add a live migration regression test

Add a live migration regression functional test
for bug 1815153 and fix some nits in
I2131558f0edfe603ee1e8d8bae66a3caf5182a58.

Change-Id: I181dff387e78064b64d46c31b35c419e527fcac8
Related-Bug: #1815153

commit_message:
List/show all server migration types

Add 'server migration list' and 'server migration show' command.

* openstack server migration list [--type <type>] [--long] <server>
* openstack server migration show <server> <migration>

Depends-On: I02305d3df61b7a37e20d3f5339e4820f83a0693d
Depends-On: I96ee551cac0b10c40b6f9edc5d068e91b6c84406
Change-Id: Ib3c4de29db2cc7778da23dc074646fa4d8200e46
Implements: blueprint list-show-all-server-migration-types

commit_message:
compute: Extract _get_bdm_image_metadata into nova.utils

This function extracts image metadata from a given block_device_mapping
and is extremely useful outside of the compute API. This change simply
extracts the function into nova.utils alongside
get_image_metadata_from_volume and other similar functions.

Change-Id: I8ba52f0cd877cefc1f7d3c10d8a07a2a1c21cb34

commit_message:
libvirt: Break up get_disk_mapping within blockinfo

As requested in I0e1241ae691afd2af12ef15706c454c05d9f932c this change
simply breaks up the huge get_disk_mapping function into smaller self
contained functions.

Change-Id: Ia15f9281ed1efcb89a83f6ef426b3294754f2bc5

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-27 17:11:46.000000000', 'message': "Provide the parent pGPU when creating a new vGPU

Now that all compute node Resource Providers are reshaped (since Stein), we
know that each of them have children RPs if they have pGPUs.

That's why we can now pass the parent PCI ID (for the pGPU) when wanting
to create a new vGPU (ie. a mdev for libvirt).

Partially-Implements: bp/vgpu-multiple-types

Change-Id: I6a1cebb6676b20b76e451fc3bde5ea54bbf16ff7
"}, {'created': '2020-04-01 10:06:51.000000000', 'message': "Provide the parent pGPU when creating a new vGPU

Now that all compute node Resource Providers are reshaped (since Stein), we
know that each of them have children RPs if they have pGPUs.

That's why we can now pass the parent PCI ID (for the pGPU) when wanting
to create a new vGPU (ie. a mdev for libvirt).

NOTE(sbauza) : The current reshape functional test for VGPUs simulates
an old compute (pre-Stein) by creating by hand VGPU inventories on the
root RP and then creating the instances to the Nova API for making sure
that the guest XML will be written. This is OK but requires the
_allocate_mdev() code to be able to support non-reshaped VGPU inventories.
Given moving to grenade checking the VGPU reshape testing wouldn't be
trivial, we accept to still provide support for non-nested RPs in this
specific _allocate_mdevs() libvirt. This sucks a bit, but that doesn't harm.

Partially-Implements: bp/vgpu-multiple-types

Change-Id: I6a1cebb6676b20b76e451fc3bde5ea54bbf16ff7
"}, {'created': '2020-04-01 13:36:10.000000000', 'message': "Provide the parent pGPU when creating a new vGPU

Partially-Implements: bp/vgpu-multiple-types

Given moving to grenade checking the VGPU reshape testing wouldn't be
trivial, we accept to still provide support for non-nested RPs in this
specific _allocate_mdevs() libvirt. This sucks a bit, but we need to

Partially-Implements: bp/vgpu-multiple-types

Change-Id: I6a1cebb6676b20b76e451fc3bde5ea54bbf16ff7
"}, {'created': '2020-04-07 08:51:44.000000000', 'message': "Provide the parent pGPU when creating a new vGPU

Now that all compute node Resource Providers are reshaped (since Stein),
we know that each of them have children RPs if they have pGPUs.

That's why we can now pass the parent PCI ID (for the pGPU) when wanting
to create a new vGPU (ie. a mdev for libvirt).

NOTE(sbauza) : The current reshape functional test for VGPUs simulates
an old compute (pre-Stein) by creating by hand VGPU inventories on the
root RP and then creating the instances to the Nova API for making sure
that the guest XML will be written. This is OK but requires the
_allocate_mdev() code to be able to support non-reshaped VGPU
inventories.
Given moving to grenade checking the VGPU reshape testing wouldn't be
trivial, we accept to still provide support for non-nested RPs in this
specific _allocate_mdevs() libvirt. This sucks a bit, but we need to
keep it for a while and that doesn't harm.

Partially-Implements: bp/vgpu-multiple-types

Change-Id: I6a1cebb6676b20b76e451fc3bde5ea54bbf16ff7
"}, {'created': '2020-04-07 20:50:44.000000000', 'message': "Provide the parent pGPU when creating a new vGPU

Now that all compute node Resource Providers are reshaped (since Stein),
we know that each of them have children RPs if they have pGPUs.

That's why we can now pass the parent PCI ID (for the pGPU) when wanting
to create a new vGPU (ie. a mdev for libvirt).

NOTE(sbauza) : The current reshape functional test for VGPUs simulates
an old compute (pre-Stein) by creating by hand VGPU inventories on the
root RP and then creating the instances to the Nova API for making sure
that the guest XML will be written. This is OK but requires the
_allocate_mdev() code to be able to support non-reshaped VGPU
inventories.
Given moving to grenade checking the VGPU reshape testing wouldn't be
trivial, we accept to still provide support for non-nested RPs in this
specific _allocate_mdevs() libvirt. This sucks a bit, but we need to
keep it for a while and that doesn't harm.

Partially-Implements: blueprint vgpu-multiple-types

Change-Id: I6a1cebb6676b20b76e451fc3bde5ea54bbf16ff7
"}]
commit_message:
Provide the parent pGPU when creating a new vGPU

Now that all compute node Resource Providers are reshaped (since Stein),
we know that each of them have children RPs if they have pGPUs.

That's why we can now pass the parent PCI ID (for the pGPU) when wanting
to create a new vGPU (ie. a mdev for libvirt).

NOTE(sbauza) : The current reshape functional test for VGPUs simulates
an old compute (pre-Stein) by creating by hand VGPU inventories on the
root RP and then creating the instances to the Nova API for making sure
that the guest XML will be written. This is OK but requires the
_allocate_mdev() code to be able to support non-reshaped VGPU
inventories.
Given moving to grenade checking the VGPU reshape testing wouldn't be
trivial, we accept to still provide support for non-nested RPs in this
specific _allocate_mdevs() libvirt. This sucks a bit, but we need to
keep it for a while and that doesn't harm.

Partially-Implements: blueprint vgpu-multiple-types

Change-Id: I6a1cebb6676b20b76e451fc3bde5ea54bbf16ff7

commit_message:
Release final python-novaclient for ussuri

Final ussuri client lib release for the April 9 deadline.

Please leave +1 if we are all set and can proceed. Leave -1 if we
need to wait a little bit longer for something final to land,
then update it with a better commit hash to use for the release
when ready.

Patches with no response will be approved a few days after the
deadline.

Change-Id: Ib6dfb66f318129b11e10ab5084ccd9c6a5291856
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Change-Id: I18032bd40489c4b1c511713b0f1c5bb1aca7c1d2

'}, {'created': '2020-01-31 12:58:13.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Report COMPUTE_RESCUE_BFV and check during rescue

This change introduces the COMPUTE_RESCUE_BFV trait and checks that a
given compute reports it when attempting to rescue a boot from volume
instance.

An additional kwarg ``allow_bfv_rescue`` flag is also added to the
signature of the rescue method within the compute API. This defaults to
False and will be used in a following change to indicate when the
request is using a high enough microversion to invoke this new
capability.

Implements: blueprint virt-bfv-instance-rescue
Change-Id: Ic2ad1468d31b7707b7f8f2b845a9cf47d9d076d5
'}, {'created': '2020-02-04 10:45:08.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Report COMPUTE_RESCUE_BFV and check during rescue

This change introduces and checks the COMPUTE_RESCUE_BFV trait in the
compute layer during an instance rescue when the instance boots from a
volume.

An additional kwarg ``allow_bfv_rescue`` flag is also added to the
signature of the rescue method within the compute API. This defaults to
False and will be used in a following change to indicate when the
request is using a high enough microversion to invoke this new
capability.

The ``supports_bfv_rescue`` capability tracked within the virt drivers
that this trait maps to is only added to the powervm driver for now due
to the way in which these capabilities are checked by the
``TestPowerVMDriver.test_driver_capabilities`` test.

Implements: blueprint virt-bfv-instance-rescue
Change-Id: Ic2ad1468d31b7707b7f8f2b845a9cf47d9d076d5

commit_message:
compute: Report COMPUTE_RESCUE_BFV and check during rescue

This change introduces and checks the COMPUTE_RESCUE_BFV trait that was
introduced in os-traits 2.2.0 in the compute layer during an instance
rescue when the instance boots from a volume.

An additional kwarg ``allow_bfv_rescue`` flag is also added to the
signature of the rescue method within the compute API. This defaults to
False and will be used in a following change to indicate when the
request is using a high enough microversion to invoke this new
capability.

The ``supports_bfv_rescue`` capability tracked within the virt drivers
that this trait maps to is only added to the powervm driver for now due
to the way in which these capabilities are checked by the
``TestPowerVMDriver.test_driver_capabilities`` test.

Implements: blueprint virt-bfv-instance-rescue
Change-Id: Ic2ad1468d31b7707b7f8f2b845a9cf47d9d076d5

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I749d6ebdef9163ffa3135778a4accbb8be5ba9e3

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-10 20:21:25.000000000', 'message': '[CI] Stop gating with manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm

The job manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm is functionally
identical to manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm-ipv6-only.
Semantically, the only difference being that the service
host, and in turn the endpoint base for manila, and the
communication address for rabbitmq, mysql and other infra
services.

manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm-ipv6-only
has MANILA_SERVICE_HOST set to an IPv6 address,
for example:
MANILA_SERVICE_HOST='[::1]'
MANILA_ENDPOINT_BASE='http://[::1]:8786'

manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm has MANILA_SERVICE_HOST
set to an IPv4 address, for example:
MANILA_SERVICE_HOST='23.253.236.222'
MANILA_ENDPOINT_BASE='http://23.253.236.222:8786'

So lets drop the job enforcing IPv4 service host since
we have coverage for that scenario in other jobs that
we're running, including the voting
manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-dummy job.

I'd like to backport this change to stable/train
during which this job was duplicated to cover the scenario
of doing "ipv6-only" service host testing [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/682716/

Change-Id: I51dc25889c1d1fb361f0be6f8c0aa47ca64c9aaa
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
[CI] Stop gating with manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm

The job manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm is functionally
identical to manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm-ipv6-only.
Semantically, the only difference being that the service
host, and in turn the endpoint base for manila, and the
communication address for rabbitmq, mysql and other infra
services.

manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm-ipv6-only
has MANILA_SERVICE_HOST set to an IPv6 address,
for example:
MANILA_SERVICE_HOST='[::1]'
MANILA_ENDPOINT_BASE='http://[::1]:8786'

manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-lvm has MANILA_SERVICE_HOST
set to an IPv4 address, for example:
MANILA_SERVICE_HOST='23.253.236.222'
MANILA_ENDPOINT_BASE='http://23.253.236.222:8786'

So lets drop the job enforcing IPv4 service host since
we have coverage for that scenario in other jobs that
we're running, including the voting
manila-tempest-minimal-dsvm-dummy job.

I'd like to backport this change to stable/train
during which this job was duplicated to cover the scenario
of doing "ipv6-only" service host testing [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/682716/

Change-Id: I51dc25889c1d1fb361f0be6f8c0aa47ca64c9aaa
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-07 10:54:19.000000000', 'message': "[NetApp] Fix driver to honor standard extra specs

During migration and manage/unmanage operations, if we used standard
extra_specs format (e.g. 'thin_provisioning'='True') instead of
NetApp based extra_specs format (e.g. 'netapp:thin_provisioned'='True'),
NetApp driver used to ignore these standard extra_specs settings
and continued the operation with the default option.
The driver is now fixed to handle this issue by honouring the
standard extra_specs during migration and manage/unmanage.

Change-Id: I48f4d966201fc8d6bd6eec0c37f1575b434310e7
Closes-Bug: #1707084
(cherry picked from commit 9250e02b56fa4a0d93fe4c32cdfac4eceab8d095)
"}]
commit_message:
[NetApp] Fix driver to honor standard extra specs

During migration and manage/unmanage operations, if we used standard
extra_specs format (e.g. 'thin_provisioning'='True') instead of
NetApp based extra_specs format (e.g. 'netapp:thin_provisioned'='True'),
NetApp driver used to ignore these standard extra_specs settings
and continued the operation with the default option.
The driver is now fixed to handle this issue by honouring the
standard extra_specs during migration and manage/unmanage.

Change-Id: I48f4d966201fc8d6bd6eec0c37f1575b434310e7
Closes-Bug: #1707084
(cherry picked from commit 9250e02b56fa4a0d93fe4c32cdfac4eceab8d095)

I2cc721676005536b14995980f7a042991c92adcc switched to using TripleoInventories
for both single and multi stack inventories. However the 'plan' undercloud var
was no longer set.

commit_message:
Include uc plan var when TripleoInventories contains a single plan

I2cc721676005536b14995980f7a042991c92adcc switched to using TripleoInventories
for both single and multi stack inventories. However the 'plan' undercloud var
was no longer set.
Restore this for single stack inventories only to keep compatibility.

Change-Id: I5735cfaa5fe59eabde66b3370a2c5838ff0c4b23
Related-bug: #1849073

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

Make a few cleanups:
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Switch to using sphinx-build
- Switch to openstackdocstheme, update requirements for this
- Cleanup doc/source/conf.py to remove now obsolete content.
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine

Change-Id: If26e126d88b33cd45a72932d1b271f7f08d50652

commit_message:
Update master for stable/ussuri

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/ussuri.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/ussuri.

Change-Id: I15fca41fbe715469ccc22389de9cbf526ae3f211
Sem-Ver: feature

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-31 14:33:52.000000000', 'message': 'WIP libvirt: Add support for stable device rescue

This change introduces a new method of instance rescue to the Libvirt
driver where the original storage devices remain attached in their
original order to the instance during a rescue. This differs from the
original method where only the rescue disk, original root disk and
recreated config drive would be attached.

This new method is controlled by the presence of hw_rescue_device and
hw_rescue_bus image metadata properties on the image provided as part of
the request to rescue the instance. As their name suggests these
properties control the device and bus type used to attach the rescue
device to the instance. Allowing users to rescue instances using more
traditional media such as USB disks or CD-ROM ISOs.

While the rescue disk is attached last to the instance we are able to
boot directly from it using the boot element and order attribute when
defining the disk within the Libvirt domain [1]. This is not however
supported for Xen or LXC virt types and as a result this new method is
not available for these types.

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsNICSBoot

Change-Id: I0e1241ae691afd2af12ef15706c454c05d9f932c
'}, {'created': '2019-12-31 15:27:40.000000000', 'message': 'WIP libvirt: Add support for stable device rescue

This change introduces a new method of instance rescue to the Libvirt
driver where the original storage devices remain attached in their
original order to the instance during a rescue. This differs from the
original method where only the rescue disk, original root disk and
recreated config drive would be attached.

This new method is controlled by the presence of hw_rescue_device and
hw_rescue_bus image metadata properties on the image provided as part of
the request to rescue the instance. As their name suggests these
properties control the device and bus type used to attach the rescue
device to the instance. Allowing users to rescue instances using more
traditional media such as USB disks or CD-ROM ISOs.

While the rescue disk is attached last to the instance we are able to
boot directly from it using the boot element and order attribute when
defining the disk within the Libvirt domain [1]. This is not however
supported for Xen or LXC virt types and as a result this new method is
not available for these types.

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsNICSBoot

Change-Id: I0e1241ae691afd2af12ef15706c454c05d9f932c
'}, {'created': '2020-01-01 19:43:32.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Add support for stable device rescue

This change introduces a new method of instance rescue to the Libvirt
driver where all original devices remain attached in their original
order. This differs from the original method of instance rescue where
only the rescue boot disk, original root disk and optional regenerated
config drive would be attached.

This new method is controlled and enabled by the presence of
hw_rescue_device and hw_rescue_bus image metadata properties on the
image provided as part of rescue request. As their name suggests these
properties control the device and bus type used to attach the rescue
boot device to the instance. The properties will allow users to rescue
instances using more traditional bare metal rescue media such as USB
disks or CD-ROM ISOs.

While the rescue disk is attached last to the instance we are able to
boot directly from it using the boot element and order attribute when
defining the disk within the Libvirt domain [1]. This is not however
supported for Xen or LXC virt types and as a result this new method is
not available for these types.

To enable this new mode and building on I9c2d9013d741774e521021913ec0 we
can now provide the full block_device_info for the instance when
building the disk mapping where we now add the rescue boot device. This
now allows instances with attached volumes to be rescued. Boot from
volume instances however are still not supported and blocked within the
compute API. Future work will remove this restriction.

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsNICSBoot

Change-Id: I0e1241ae691afd2af12ef15706c454c05d9f932c
'}, {'created': '2020-01-07 19:15:22.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Add support for stable device rescue

This change introduces a new method of instance rescue to the Libvirt
driver where all original devices remain attached in their original
order. This differs from the original method of instance rescue where
only the rescue boot disk, original root disk and optional regenerated
config drive would be attached.

This new method is controlled and enabled by the presence of
hw_rescue_device and hw_rescue_bus image metadata properties on the
image provided as part of rescue request. As their name suggests these
properties control the device and bus type used to attach the rescue
boot device to the instance. The properties will allow users to rescue
instances using more traditional bare metal rescue media such as USB
disks or CD-ROM ISOs.

While the rescue disk is attached last to the instance we are able to
boot directly from it using the boot element and order attribute when
defining the disk within the Libvirt domain [1]. This is not however
supported for Xen or LXC virt types and as a result this new method is
not available for these types.

To enable this new mode and building on I9c2d9013d741774e521021913ec0 we
can now provide the full block_device_info for the instance when
building the disk mapping where we now add the rescue boot device. This
now allows instances with attached volumes to be rescued. Boot from
volume instances however are still not supported and blocked within the
compute API. Future work will remove this restriction.

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsNICSBoot

Change-Id: I0e1241ae691afd2af12ef15706c454c05d9f932c

instance. The properties will allow users to rescue instances using the
emulated equivalents of more traditional bare metal rescue media such as
USB disks or CD-ROM ISOs.

While the rescue disk is attached last to the instance we are able to
boot directly from it using the boot element and order attribute when
defining the disk within the Libvirt domain [1]. This is not however
supported for Xen or LXC virt types and as a result this new method is
not available for these types.

To enable this new mode and building on I9c2d9013d741774e521021913ec0 we
can now provide the full block_device_info for the instance when
building the disk mapping where we now add the rescue boot device. This
now allows instances with attached volumes to be rescued. Boot from
volume instances however are still not supported and blocked within the
compute API. Future work will remove this restriction.

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsNICSBoot

Implements: blueprint virt-rescue-stable-disk-devices
Change-Id: I0e1241ae691afd2af12ef15706c454c05d9f932c
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Add support for stable device rescue

This change introduces a new method of instance rescue to the Libvirt
driver where all original devices remain attached in their original
order while booting from the provided rescue image. This differs from
the original method of instance rescue where only the rescue disk,
original root disk and regenerated config drive would be attached.

This new method is enabled by the presence of either the
hw_rescue_device or hw_rescue_bus image metadata properties on the
provided rescue image. As their name suggests these properties control
the device and bus type used to attach the rescue boot device to the
instance. The properties will allow users to rescue instances using the
emulated equivalents of more traditional bare metal rescue media such as
USB disks or CD-ROM ISOs.

While the rescue disk is attached last to the instance we are able to
boot directly from it using the boot element and order attribute when
defining the disk within the Libvirt domain [1]. This is not however
supported for Xen or LXC virt types and as a result this new method is
not available for these types.

To enable this new mode and building on I9c2d9013d741774e521021913ec0 we
can now provide the full block_device_info for the instance when
building the disk mapping where we now add the rescue boot device. This
now allows instances with attached volumes to be rescued. Boot from
volume instances however are still not supported and blocked within the
compute API. Future work will remove this restriction.

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsNICSBoot

Implements: blueprint virt-rescue-stable-disk-devices
Change-Id: I0e1241ae691afd2af12ef15706c454c05d9f932c

commit_message:
Use placement stable version for functional job

nova-tox-functional is py2 job and need placement as required project.
and started failing for incompatible py version:

ERROR: Package 'openstack-placement' requires a different Python: 2.7.17 not in '>=3.6'

- https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/b460a8c59ad64e57b871aa3c00638b01/log/job-output.txt#782

Placement master is now py3 only which mean master version will stop
working on py2 env:
- I6f458fb60b5a33b5aa2ce3ab292862ab98eb4670

Current tox env mention the placement master link as deps, where need to use
the stable version for stable jobs. Making deps with version not the
fresh git clone like how other test-requirements.txt deps work.

Change-Id: Ib5f70f4bbfde8672507adebdbc4e411b5db39bb8

commit_message:
Use placement stable branch version for functional job

nova-tox-functional is py2 job and need placement as required project.
and started failing for incompatible py version:

ERROR: Package 'openstack-placement' requires a different Python: 2.7.17 not in '>=3.6'

- https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/b460a8c59ad64e57b871aa3c00638b01/log/job-output.txt#782

Placement master is now py3 only which mean master version will stop
working on py2 env:
- I6f458fb60b5a33b5aa2ce3ab292862ab98eb4670

We should use the stable version of placement on stable jobs.

Change-Id: Ib5f70f4bbfde8672507adebdbc4e411b5db39bb8

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I979c219b5ddc2ef709173b17a29172f18ff15cae

commit_message:
Microversion 2.87 - Stable device boot from volume rescue

This microversion is used to request a stable device rescue for boot
from volume instances and will only succeed when the compute hosting the
instance reports the COMPUTE_RESCUE_BFV trait.

No changes are required within novaclient so this change only bumps
API_MAX_VERSION.


Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701430/

Change-Id: I7885b8558db7657abbfe1f45877f52e947f5f655

CI: do 12 attempts to connect to test instance

AArch64 needs a bit more time to boot testing instance. So give it more
time by doubling amount of connect attempts.

Change-Id: I87ca65691dfbac84349e8af24d2f36f1db1c8be1

This patch adds a periodic job to build the amphora image using the
released version of diskimage-builder (our other jobs use Git master).
This job will not publish the produced image, it is only to test the
build.

Change-Id: I611d9cd5a519abc6a330ec2c46a2f5a1fdb89313

commit_message:
Add a periodic image build job

This patch adds a periodic job to build the amphora image using the
released version of diskimage-builder (our other jobs use Git master).
This job will not publish the produced image, it is only to test the
build.

Change-Id: I611d9cd5a519abc6a330ec2c46a2f5a1fdb89313
(cherry picked from commit 1f9915037ad68356231691607b461c30b28df3b7)

commit_message:
Fix the interface filenames for Red Hat amphora images

Code was not using the correct filenames for the 'route',
'route6', 'rule' and 'rule6' files on Red Hat images.
Changed to use config option 'agent_server_network_file'
if it's specified, else the file of the correct name, and
added unit tests for each.

Conflicts:
  octavia/amphorae/backends/agent/api_server/osutils.py
  octavia/tests/unit/amphorae/backends/agent/api_server/test_osutils.py

Change-Id: I335287da66524d026f0c42086d885b478c568bbd
Task: 37881
Story: 2007051
(cherry picked from commit 93cd9fc075b3d77490090b89e449f18938710b26)

loadbalancer we allow the tenant to define more fine grain access
policies their loadbalancer, such as only enabling access to a given
port/protocol from a given remote id or subnet CIDR -- instead of
having to open that port/protocol from everywhere.

As this security group is only used for the amphora VM created for
the specific load balancer, and the user could already open access
to it through listeners on any port, protocol, giving full access to
modify the SG will not entitle any extra security concern.

Note this can be a temporal solution until Octavia enables this
flexibility through their own API

(cherry picked from: I2346c8a3f2fa4b4eb8a004b4aaab93986228c371)

commit_message:
Enabling SG customization on loadbalancer listerners

By changing the SG ownership to belong to the tenant creating the
loadbalancer we allow the tenant to define more fine grain access
policies their loadbalancer, such as only enabling access to a given
port/protocol from a given remote id or subnet CIDR -- instead of
having to open that port/protocol from everywhere.

As this security group is only used for the amphora VM created for
the specific load balancer, and the user could already open access
to it through listeners on any port, protocol, giving full access to
modify the SG will not entitle any extra security concern.

Note this can be a temporal solution until Octavia enables this
flexibility through their own API

(cherry picked from: I2346c8a3f2fa4b4eb8a004b4aaab93986228c371)

Change-Id: I2346c8a3f2fa4b4eb8a004b4aaab93986228c371
Story: 2003686

These tasks are only working & tested on Podman; let's skip them if

commit_message:
WIP: Fix NFS volume retype with migrate

(Hijacking this patch to test a change to .zuul.yaml to see if it
fixes the gate.)

When migrating a volume to an NFS backend, don't rename the associated
volume file if the original source volume was on the same backend (same
provider_location). Volume migration always deletes the source volume,
so the volume file should *not* be renamed to the original.

Closes-Bug: #1798468
Change-Id: Iadf537521af93bbd28452a54e0e70e7ed18f606c
(cherry picked from commit 33a3a4bf6fe72b093702922e2e5f102d06249375)
(cherry picked from commit 6f3bec3c64e27f7daac830e62de935b2d5ffa20f)
(cherry picked from commit 058700edc93a5815bedc8c7f53cccd672618019c)
(cherry picked from commit f3639046cbdc5202340ffd7a691c21ce3b6cc1bf)
(cherry picked from commit 01d3d2ee242f265ce9639349a8353891284c8142)
(cherry picked from commit 936a4aef6e02b6f8d96cb3510ca94c2b17eb73cd)
Conflicts:
	cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/test_nfs.py

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-08 21:19:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix multistack inventory

The static inventory merging was setting the role hosts to the _meta hostvars.
This is a special key to set hostvars for dynamic inventories. It contains all
hosts in the inventory to prevent the dynamic inventory script being called
with --host for each host.

It was not used by the single stack inventory when generating a static
inventory. Instead an evil magic flag (host_format_dict), switched the
behaviour to embed the hostvars.

This flag is now removed and replaced with a param to the list method and
calling the write_static_inventory methods no longer magically mutates
the object. The logic for static vs dynamic inventory should be clearer.

The interface for the multi stack inventory has also change to be more
consistent with the single stack interface.

Unit tests now cover both static and dynamic multistack inventories.

Change-Id: Ife14dbe04dd11db44a944f98373f63e01dfbb8d8
Depends-On: If022a4647aaebc4b212bba188cc959ff2f8f9311
Closes-bug: #1849073
(cherry picked from commit f2e833e74a213f5c011154e76fa25e36f9f29009)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix multistack inventory

The static inventory merging was setting the role hosts to the _meta hostvars.
This is a special key to set hostvars for dynamic inventories. It contains all
hosts in the inventory to prevent the dynamic inventory script being called
with --host for each host.

It was not used by the single stack inventory when generating a static
inventory. Instead an evil magic flag (host_format_dict), switched the
behaviour to embed the hostvars.

This flag is now removed and replaced with a param to the list method and
calling the write_static_inventory methods no longer magically mutates
the object. The logic for static vs dynamic inventory should be clearer.

The interface for the multi stack inventory has also change to be more
consistent with the single stack interface.

Unit tests now cover both static and dynamic multistack inventories.

Change-Id: Ife14dbe04dd11db44a944f98373f63e01dfbb8d8
Depends-On: If022a4647aaebc4b212bba188cc959ff2f8f9311
Closes-bug: #1849073
(cherry picked from commit f2e833e74a213f5c011154e76fa25e36f9f29009)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-08 11:49:49.000000000', 'message': 'Preserve existing placement password during extraction

nova-placement previously used NovaPassword. When it was split out into
the standalone placement service a new password param was added.

This patch ensures that when the extraction occurs, PlacementPassword
defaults to the existing NovaPassword value so that we do not have to
update the placement password in keystone.
Works around the fact that the upgrade playbook currently does not run
the required tasks to update keystone resources.
